<p>The <b>2011 <a href="/wiki/World_Artistic_Gymnastics_Championships" title="World Artistic Gymnastics Championships">World Artistic Gymnastics Championships</a></b> were held in <a href="/wiki/Tokyo" title="Tokyo">Tokyo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Japan" title="Japan">Japan</a>, from October 7¨C16, 2011 at the <a href="/wiki/Tokyo_Metropolitan_Gymnasium" title="Tokyo Metropolitan Gymnasium">Tokyo Metropolitan Gymnasium</a>. Due to uncertainty over the nuclear situation following the <a href="/wiki/2011_T%C5%8Dhoku_earthquake_and_tsunami" title="2011 T¨­hoku earthquake and tsunami">2011 T¨­hoku earthquake and tsunami</a>, the <a href="/wiki/F%C3%A9d%C3%A9ration_Internationale_de_Gymnastique" title="F¨¦d¨¦ration Internationale de Gymnastique" class="mw-redirect">International Federation of Gymnastics</a> revealed it was considering moving the event,<sup id="cite_ref-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup> but on May 22 FIG president <a href="/wiki/Bruno_Grandi" title="Bruno Grandi">Bruno Grandi</a> announced that the World Championships would take place in Tokyo as planned.<sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2"><span>[</span>2<span>]</span></a></sup></p>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Olympic_qualification">Olympic qualification</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=2011_World_Artistic_Gymnastics_Championships&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2" title="Edit section: Olympic qualification">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<div class="rellink relarticle mainarticle">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Gymnastics_at_the_2012_Summer_Olympics_%E2%80%93_Qualification" title="Gymnastics at the 2012 Summer Olympics ¨C Qualification">Gymnastics at the 2012 Summer Olympics ¨C Qualification</a></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Teams">Teams</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=2011_World_Artistic_Gymnastics_Championships&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3" title="Edit section: Teams">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>This event is the first qualifying stage for the <a href="/wiki/2012_Summer_Olympics" title="2012 Summer Olympics">2012 Summer Olympics</a> which will be held in <a href="/wiki/London" title="London">London</a>. The top 24 men's and women's teams from the <a href="/wiki/2010_World_Artistic_Gymnastics_Championships" title="2010 World Artistic Gymnastics Championships">2010 World Artistic Gymnastics Championships</a> are allowed to send a full team of gymnasts. The top 8 men's and women's teams will directly qualify for the team events at the 2012 Olympics. Teams placed 9th to 16th will get a second chance to qualify a full team at the Olympic Test Event in January 10¨C18, 2012, from which four men's and women's teams will qualify.</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Individuals">Individuals</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=2011_World_Artistic_Gymnastics_Championships&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4" title="Edit section: Individuals">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>The winners of gold, silver and bronze medals in each apparatus will qualify for the Olympics, either as individuals or as members of their national team. Additional individual gymnasts will qualify from the Test Event in January.</p>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Women.27s_results">Women's results</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=2011_World_Artistic_Gymnastics_Championships&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7" title="Edit section: Women's results">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p><a href="/wiki/2011_World_Artistic_Gymnastics_Championships_%E2%80%93_Women%27s_qualification" title="2011 World Artistic Gymnastics Championships ¨C Women's qualification">2011 World Artistic Gymnastics Championships ¨C Women's qualification</a></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Team_all-around">Team all-around</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=2011_World_Artistic_Gymnastics_Championships&amp;action=edit&amp;section=8" title="Edit section: Team all-around">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>In the qualifying round, five gymnasts performed on each apparatus, and the top four scores were counted towards the team's total. The top eight teams qualified to the final.<sup id="cite_ref-wtq_3-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wtq-3"><span>[</span>3<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>In the final, held on October 11, only three gymnasts performed on each apparatus, and all the scores counted. The United States team won the gold medal with solid performances by all gymnasts on all apparatus, while the Russian team made several mistakes and finished a distant second. China narrowly beat Romania to win the bronze medal, followed by Great Britain in fifth place.<sup id="cite_ref-wtf_4-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wtf-4"><span>[</span>4<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-wtfr_5-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wtfr-5"><span>[</span>5<span>]</span></a></sup> This was the highest ranking finish Great Britain had ever had for a team at a World Championship.<sup id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6"><span>[</span>6<span>]</span></a></sup></p>

<p><b>Controversy</b></p>
<p>During the presentation of medals, the <a href="/wiki/Star-Spangled_Banner" title="Star-Spangled Banner" class="mw-redirect">National Anthem of the United States</a> was abruptly ended, causing some frustration amongst both the coaches and the gymnasts themselves.</p>
<ul>
<li>Alicia Sacramone injured her Achilles tendon during the last Podium training and had already left Japan when the Team Final started. However, US National Team Coordinator Marta Karolyi opted to keep her on the roster instead of officially naming alternate Anna Li to the team and subsequently competed with only 5 instead of the usual 6 gymnasts. This led to Alicia Sacramone receiving her tenth World Championships medal and officially becoming the US gymnast with the most World Championship medals. As Sacramone was not present during the competition <a href="/wiki/Anna_Li" title="Anna Li">Anna Li</a> dressed, supported the team on the floor, and accepted the team medal for Alicia. Anna Li later passed the medal on to Sacramone and received (as costumary for the World team alternates) a copy from USAG.</li>
</ul>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Individual_all-around">Individual all-around</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=2011_World_Artistic_Gymnastics_Championships&amp;action=edit&amp;section=9" title="Edit section: Individual all-around">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>The final was held on October 13. None of the medallists from the previous year were able to compete to defend their title as the Gold and Bronze medallists -<a href="/wiki/Aliya_Mustafina" title="Aliya Mustafina">Aliya Mustafina</a> and <a href="/wiki/Rebecca_Bross" title="Rebecca Bross">Rebecca Bross</a> - were both unable to compete at worlds due to knee injuries and Silver medallist, Jiang did not qualify high enough over teammates. A number of gymnasts ranked high enough to make the all-around final, but did not qualify due to the 2-per-country rule. All the gymnasts from the USA that competed in the preliminary round had ranked in the top 24. The gymnasts affected were <a href="/wiki/Gabby_Douglas" title="Gabby Douglas">Gabby Douglas</a> (5th), <a href="/wiki/Sabrina_Vega" title="Sabrina Vega">Sabrina Vega</a> (9th), and <a href="/wiki/McKayla_Maroney" title="McKayla Maroney">McKayla Maroney</a> (12th) of the United States. Also affected were <a href="/wiki/Tan_Sixin" title="Tan Sixin">Tan Sixin</a> (15th) and <a href="/wiki/Yuyuan_Jiang" title="Yuyuan Jiang" class="mw-redirect">Yuyuan Jiang</a> (20th) of China, <a href="/wiki/Yuko_Shintake" title="Yuko Shintake">Yuko Shintake</a> (21st) and <a href="/wiki/Yu_Minobe" title="Yu Minobe">Yu Minobe</a> (23rd) of Japan, and <a href="/wiki/Anna_Dementyeva" title="Anna Dementyeva">Anna Dementyeva</a> (31st) of Russia. In the end the last gymnast to qualify was <a href="/wiki/Carlotta_Ferlito" title="Carlotta Ferlito">Carlotta Ferlito</a> who had ranked 32nd in the prelimary competition.</p>

<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Vault">Vault</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=2011_World_Artistic_Gymnastics_Championships&amp;action=edit&amp;section=10" title="Edit section: Vault">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>Phan's Bronze medal was the first medal for Vietnam at a World Championships. Maroney's performance secured the 3rd consecutive World Gold medal for the USA on women's vault following <a href="/wiki/Kayla_Williams_(gymnast)" title="Kayla Williams (gymnast)">Kayla Williams</a> in 2009 and teammate <a href="/wiki/Alicia_Sacramone" title="Alicia Sacramone">Alicia Sacramone</a> in 2010. Chusovitina's Silver was her 11th world medal (her 9th vault world medal). As her first world championships was in Indianapolis in 1991, she has been competing at an International level since before her fellow vault finialists were born.</p>

<p>On the day before the competition, it was announced that <a href="/wiki/Diana_Bulimar" title="Diana Bulimar">Diana Bulimar</a> had injured her foot, and so 1st reserve <a href="/wiki/Lauren_Mitchell" title="Lauren Mitchell">Lauren Mitchell</a> would be taking her place in the final. Shortly after the women's beam competition, it was announced that Russia had decided to pull <a href="/wiki/Viktoria_Komova" title="Viktoria Komova">Viktoria Komova</a> from the competition to give her teammate (and 2nd reserve), <a href="/wiki/Ksenia_Afanasyeva" title="Ksenia Afanasyeva">Ksenia Afanasyeva</a> a chance to compete in the final instead. During the warm up <a href="/wiki/Vanessa_Ferrari" title="Vanessa Ferrari">Vanessa Ferrari</a> injured herself and so 3rd reserve <a href="/wiki/Diana_Chelaru" title="Diana Chelaru">Diana Chelaru</a> was quickly added to replace her.</p>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Men.27s_results">Men's results</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=2011_World_Artistic_Gymnastics_Championships&amp;action=edit&amp;section=14" title="Edit section: Men's results">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Team_all-around_2">Team all-around</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=2011_World_Artistic_Gymnastics_Championships&amp;action=edit&amp;section=15" title="Edit section: Team all-around">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>In the qualifying round, five gymnasts performed on each apparaus, and the top four scores were counted towards the team's total. The top eight teams qualified to the final.<sup id="cite_ref-mtq_7-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-mtq-7"><span>[</span>7<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>In the final, held on October 12, only three gymnasts performed on each apparatus, and all the scores were counted. The Chineses team won the title for the fifth successive time, benefitting from crucial mistakes by the last two Japanese gymnasts. Japan was still able to win the silver medal, with a margin of only 0.010 point from the United States in bronze medal position.<sup id="cite_ref-mtf_8-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-mtf-8"><span>[</span>8<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-mtfr_9-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-mtfr-9"><span>[</span>9<span>]</span></a></sup></p>

<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Individual_all-around_2">Individual all-around</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=2011_World_Artistic_Gymnastics_Championships&amp;action=edit&amp;section=16" title="Edit section: Individual all-around">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>The all-around final was held on October 14. Three gymnasts had ranked high enough to qualify, but were not allowed to compete due to the 2-per-country rule. The affected gymnasts were <a href="/wiki/Jonathan_Horton" title="Jonathan Horton">Jonathan Horton</a> (5th), <a href="/wiki/Fabian_Hamb%C3%BCchen" title="Fabian Hamb¨¹chen">Fabian Hamb¨¹chen</a> (19th) and <a href="/wiki/Steven_Legendre" title="Steven Legendre">Steven Legendre</a> (24th). On the day of the final, <a href="/wiki/Marian_Dragulescu" title="Marian Dragulescu" class="mw-redirect">Marian Dragulescu</a> pulled out of the competition and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nathan_Gafuik&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nathan Gafuik (page does not exist)">Nathan Gafuik</a> took his place.</p>

<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Floor_2">Floor</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=2011_World_Artistic_Gymnastics_Championships&amp;action=edit&amp;section=17" title="Edit section: Floor">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>The final for Men's Floor Exercise took place on October 15. <a href="/wiki/Marian_Dragulescu" title="Marian Dragulescu" class="mw-redirect">Marian Dragulescu</a> had qualified in 2nd,<sup id="cite_ref-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-10"><span>[</span>10<span>]</span></a></sup> but pulled out of the competition on the morning of the final. As the first reserve, Jake Dalton (USA) took his place. There was also an inquiry made by the Japanese coaches into the scoring when K¨­hei Uchimura's difficulty score was only awarded a 6.500 because they had mistaken a triple twisting move for a double twisting move. The inquiry was accepted by the judges, and the score adjusted accordingly, which gave Uchimura the gold medal.</p>
